section.title: Creating a MTOM Web Service
section.para: The starting point for developing a web service to use WSIT is a Java class file annotated with the javax.jws.WebService annotation.
For detailed instructions for how to use NetBeans IDE to create a web service, see .

section.title: Configuring Message Optimization in a Web Service
section.para: To use the IDE to configure a web service for message optimization, perform the following steps.

task.title: To Configure Message Optimization in a Web Service

para.emphasis: In the IDE Projects window, expand the Web Services node, right-click the CalculatorWSService node, and choose Edit Web Service Attributes.

step.para: The Web Service Attributes editor appears.

para.emphasis: Select the Optimize Transfer of Binary Data (MTOM) check box, as shown in , and click OK.

step.para: This setting configures the web service to optimize messages that it transmits and to decode optimized messages that it receives.

section.title: Deploying and Testing a Web Service with Message Optimization Enabled
section.para: Now that you have configured the web service to use message optimization, you can deploy and test it.

section.title: Creating a Client to Consume a Message Optimization-enabled Web Service
section.para: Now that you have built and tested a web service that uses the WSIT Message Optimization technology, you can create a client that accesses and consumes that web service. The client will use the web service's WSDL to create the functionality necessary to satisfy the interoperability requirements of the web service.

section.title: Message Optimization and Secure Conversation
section.para: The Web Services Secure Conversation technology has message optimization benefits. While providing better message-level security it also improves the efficiency of multiple-message exchanges. It accomplishes this by providing basic mechanisms on top of which secure messaging semantics can be defined for multiple-message exchanges. This feature allows for contexts to be established so that potentially more efficient keys or new key material can be exchanged. The result is that the overall performance of subsequent message exchanges is improved.
